clusters.title: Judge blocks suspension of Snap food aid during shutdown – US politics live
clusters.neutral_headline: Judge Blocks Suspension of SNAP Food Aid During Shutdown

items.title: Judge blocks suspension of Snap food aid during shutdown – US politics live
items.standfirst: Federal court ruling comes hours before more than 40 million Americans could lose food stamps benefitsTrump officials blocked from suspending Snap benefits How will shutdown affect your access to food or health insuranceUS House Speaker Mike Johnson reiterated this morning that he will not bring the chamber back into session until the government shutdown ends.Speaking to Fox News on Friday, Johnson said: “We are anxious to get the house back to regular legislative session, but we have to get the lights turned back on. Chuck Schumer and the Democrats in the Senate have got to reopen the government. Again, it’s the most fundamental responsibility of congress is to have the government operate and work for the people. That’s the number one priority right now and we cannot deviate from that.” Continue reading...
items.content: Federal court ruling comes hours before more than 40 million Americans could lose food stamps benefitsTrump officials blocked from suspending Snap benefits How will shutdown affect your access to food or health insuranceUS House Speaker Mike Johnson reiterated this morning that he will not bring the chamber back into session until the government shutdown ends.Speaking to Fox News on Friday, Johnson said: “We are anxious to get the house back to regular legislative session, but we have to get the lights turned back on. Chuck Schumer and the Democrats in the Senate have got to reopen the government. Again, it’s the most fundamental responsibility of congress is to have the government operate and work for the people. That’s the number one priority right now and we cannot deviate from that.” Continue reading...

items.title: Judges say Trump administration must keep paying some SNAP benefits
items.standfirst: Two federal judges on Friday said the Trump administration must tap into contingency funds to make SNAP payments during the government shutdown.
items.content: Two federal judges on Friday said the Trump administration must tap into contingency funds to make SNAP payments during the government shutdown.

items.title: US judge blocks Trump administration from halting Snap food benefits
items.standfirst: A federal judge said the plan to suspend food aid to millions of Americans during the ongoing US government shutdown is likely unlawful.
items.content: A federal judge said the plan to suspend food aid to millions of Americans during the ongoing US government shutdown is likely unlawful.

items.title: Trump administration blocked from suspending Snap benefits for millions of Americans
items.standfirst: One judge issues temporary restraining order while another judge rules the government must continue to fund program that helps low-income householdsUS politics live – latest updatesA federal judge in Rhode Island on Friday afternoon blocked the Trump administration from suspending all food aid for millions of Americans amid the ongoing government shutdown, in a case brought by a group of US cities, nonprofit organizations and a trade union.And at almost the same time, in a separate but similar case, a federal judge in Massachusetts ruled that the government must continue to fund the program that helps low-income households stave off food insecurity, in a case brought by the Democratic attorneys general from 22 states and the District of Columbia and three governors who sued the administration. Continue reading...
items.content: One judge issues temporary restraining order while another judge rules the government must continue to fund program that helps low-income householdsUS politics live – latest updatesA federal judge in Rhode Island on Friday afternoon blocked the Trump administration from suspending all food aid for millions of Americans amid the ongoing government shutdown, in a case brought by a group of US cities, nonprofit organizations and a trade union.And at almost the same time, in a separate but similar case, a federal judge in Massachusetts ruled that the government must continue to fund the program that helps low-income households stave off food insecurity, in a case brought by the Democratic attorneys general from 22 states and the District of Columbia and three governors who sued the administration. Continue reading...

items.title: Judge gives Trump administration until Monday to have a plan for SNAP benefits
items.standfirst: Judge Indira Talwani acknowledged this will leave millions of people without assistance starting Saturday. Two dozen Democratic-led states had sued over the administration's decision to suspend SNAP.
items.content: Judge Indira Talwani acknowledged this will leave millions of people without assistance starting Saturday. Two dozen Democratic-led states had sued over the administration's decision to suspend SNAP.(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

items.title: A judge to weigh in on SNAP benefits. And, Trump wants to resume nuclear testing
items.standfirst: A federal judge is set to decide whether the Trump administration will have to find funds to keep SNAP benefits flowing. And, President Trump says the U.S. should resume nuclear weapons testing.
items.content: A federal judge is set to decide whether the Trump administration will have to find funds to keep SNAP benefits flowing. And, President Trump says the U.S. should resume nuclear weapons testing.(Image credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo)

ai_summary: A federal judge ruled against the Trump administration's plan to halt SNAP benefits.
The judge stated the plan to suspend food aid during the shutdown was likely unlawful.
The ruling came in response to a case brought by cities, nonprofits, and a trade union.
Another judge issued a similar ruling in a separate case on the same day.
The judges said the administration must use contingency funds for SNAP payments.

Continue reading...

items.title: Palace’s statement on Andrew is ‘vindication’ for Virginia Giuffre, says her family
items.standfirst: Women’s rights groups say announcement sends important message to survivors of abuseThe historic statement from Buckingham Palace stripping Andrew Mountbatten Windsor of his title is an “acknowledgment” that something happened to the late Virginia Giuffre, her family has told the Guardian.In its announcement on Thursday, the palace said Andrew Mountbatten Windsor – as he is now known – will also leave his mansion in Windsor, Royal Lodge, as his links to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein continue to cause controversy. Continue reading...

items.title: JP Morgan warned US of $1bn in Epstein transactions possibly related to human trafficking
items.standfirst: Bank says it alerted US of ‘suspicious’ transactions just weeks after paedophile was found dead in New York jail cellJP Morgan warned the US government about more than $1bn in transactions linked to Jeffrey Epstein that were possibly related to reports of human trafficking, new documents confirm.The largest bank in the US filed a suspicious activity report (SAR) in 2019, just weeks after Epstein was found dead in a New York jail cell, about transactions linked to the paedophile financier and prominent business figures. It also flagged wire transfers made by Epstein to Russian banks. Continue reading...
items.content: Bank says it alerted US of ‘suspicious’ transactions just weeks after paedophile was found dead in New York jail cellJP Morgan warned the US government about more than $1bn in transactions linked to Jeffrey Epstein that were possibly related to reports of human trafficking, new documents confirm.The largest bank in the US filed a suspicious activity report (SAR) in 2019, just weeks after Epstein was found dead in a New York jail cell, about transactions linked to the paedophile financier and prominent business figures. It also flagged wire transfers made by Epstein to Russian banks. Continue reading...

ai_summary: JP Morgan warned the US about Epstein transactions.

clusters.title: Sudan’s RSF accused of ‘PR stunt’ after arresting fighters behind civilian killings
clusters.neutral_headline: Sudan’s RSF Accused of ‘PR Stunt’ After Arresting Fighters

items.title: Sudan’s RSF accused of ‘PR stunt’ after arresting fighters behind civilian killings
items.standfirst: Reports of indiscriminate violence and ethnic targeting in El Fasher have led to growing global outrageSudan’s paramilitary Rapid Support Forces claim to have arrested several of their fighters after outrage over the extent of killing in the city of El Fasher continues to build.But the paramilitary group’s move has been greeted with scepticism from human rights campaigners and Sudanese people, who see it as an attempt to temper criticism over the violence. Continue reading...
items.content: Reports of indiscriminate violence and ethnic targeting in El Fasher have led to growing global outrageSudan’s paramilitary Rapid Support Forces claim to have arrested several of their fighters after outrage over the extent of killing in the city of El Fasher continues to build.But the paramilitary group’s move has been greeted with scepticism from human rights campaigners and Sudanese people, who see it as an attempt to temper criticism over the violence. Continue reading...

items.title: Sudan's RSF says it arrested fighters accused of El-Fasher abuses
items.standfirst: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces said they had arrested several of their fighters accused of committing abuses during the capture of the city of El-Fasher. Although the goal is to show that the RSF follows the rules of war, it's probable those arrests "are not significant at all" FRANCE 24's Bastien Renouil says from Nairobi. He tells us more on the political situation in Darfur.
items.content: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces said they had arrested several of their fighters accused of committing abuses during the capture of the city of El-Fasher. Although the goal is to show that the RSF follows the rules of war, it's probable those arrests "are not significant at all" FRANCE 24's Bastien Renouil says from Nairobi. He tells us more on the political situation in Darfur.

items.title: UN leaders condemn ‘horrifying’ mass killings in Sudan
items.standfirst: Emergency security council session criticises killings of civilians in El Fasher and external supply of arms to RSFDiplomats and senior UN figures speaking at the UN security council have condemned mass killings by the Rapid Support Forces in El Fasher after the Sudanese city “descended into an even darker hell” following the paramilitary group’s takeover at the weekend.Widespread reports of ethnically targeted killings in recent days prompted the UK, as the UN penholder on Sudan, to call an emergency session of the security council in New York on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: Emergency security council session criticises killings of civilians in El Fasher and external supply of arms to RSFDiplomats and senior UN figures speaking at the UN security council have condemned mass killings by the Rapid Support Forces in El Fasher after the Sudanese city “descended into an even darker hell” following the paramilitary group’s takeover at the weekend.Widespread reports of ethnically targeted killings in recent days prompted the UK, as the UN penholder on Sudan, to call an emergency session of the security council in New York on Thursday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Sudan's RSF arrested fighters accused of abuses.
The arrests followed outrage over killings in El Fasher.
Human rights groups are skeptical of the RSF's actions.
UN leaders condemned mass killings in Sudan.
The RSF's actions are seen as a public relations attempt.

clusters.title: Liberal-progressive party D66 wins election, Dutch media report
clusters.neutral_headline: Dutch centrist party wins election, ousting far right

items.title: Liberal-progressive party D66 wins election, Dutch media report
items.standfirst: Party will take lead in first round of talks to form coalition government after securing most votesThe Dutch liberal-progressive party D66 won the most votes in Wednesday’s general election, the news agency ANP has reported, putting its 38-year-old leader, Rob Jetten, on course to become the youngest prime minister in the Netherlands.While the last few thousand votes are still being counted, Dutch media reported on Friday that Geert Wilders’ anti-immigration, anti-Islam Party for Freedom (PVV) could no longer win. Continue reading...
items.content: Party will take lead in first round of talks to form coalition government after securing most votesThe Dutch liberal-progressive party D66 won the most votes in Wednesday’s general election, the news agency ANP has reported, putting its 38-year-old leader, Rob Jetten, on course to become the youngest prime minister in the Netherlands.While the last few thousand votes are still being counted, Dutch media reported on Friday that Geert Wilders’ anti-immigration, anti-Islam Party for Freedom (PVV) could no longer win. Continue reading...

items.title: Centrist D66 party ousts far right to win Netherlands election, local media reports
items.standfirst: The Netherlands' centrist D66 party has won the country's elections, ousting far-right leader Geert Wilders, a local news agency reported on Friday. While postal votes are still being counted, the likely narrow victory for D66 would mean its leader Rob Jetten can begin talks to form a coalition government.
items.content: The Netherlands' centrist D66 party has won the country's elections, ousting far-right leader Geert Wilders, a local news agency reported on Friday. While postal votes are still being counted, the likely narrow victory for D66 would mean its leader Rob Jetten can begin talks to form a coalition government.

ai_summary: The Dutch centrist party D66 won the most votes in the election.
D66 will lead coalition talks after securing the most votes.
The far-right leader Geert Wilders is likely to lose.
Rob Jetten, D66 leader, may become the youngest prime minister.
Postal votes are still being counted, but D66 is likely to win.

items.title: About 700 killed in Tanzania election protests, opposition says
items.standfirst: Demonstrators took to streets after president’s main challengers were excluded from ballotAbout 700 people have been killed during three days of election protests in Tanzania, the main opposition party has said.Protests erupted on election day on Wednesday over what demonstrators said was the stifling of the opposition after the exclusion of key candidates from the presidential ballot. Continue reading...
items.content: Demonstrators took to streets after president’s main challengers were excluded from ballotAbout 700 people have been killed during three days of election protests in Tanzania, the main opposition party has said.Protests erupted on election day on Wednesday over what demonstrators said was the stifling of the opposition after the exclusion of key candidates from the presidential ballot. Continue reading...

items.title: At least 700 dead in Tanzania's post-election protests, opposition says
items.standfirst: Hundreds of people have reportedly been killed in Tanzania after taking to the streets to protest this week’s presidential election, which saw the increasingly authoritarian incumbent, President Samia Suluhu Hassan, run unopposed for another term after her main challengers were jailed or barred from standing.
items.content: Hundreds of people have reportedly been killed in Tanzania after taking to the streets to protest this week’s presidential election, which saw the increasingly authoritarian incumbent, President Samia Suluhu Hassan, run unopposed for another term after her main challengers were jailed or barred from standing.

ai_summary: The opposition party reports about 700 deaths in Tanzania protests.
Protests erupted after key candidates were excluded from the ballot.
Demonstrators protested the stifling of the opposition.
The incumbent president ran unopposed for another term.
Protests occurred on election day in Tanzania.

items.title: Senate passes bill to nullify Trump’s sweeping global tariffs on more than 100 nations – as it happened
items.standfirst: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: Four Senate Republicans join Democrats to reject global tariffsIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...
items.content: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: Four Senate Republicans join Democrats to reject global tariffsIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...

items.title: US Senate votes to reject Trump’s global tariffs on more than 100 countries
items.standfirst: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to challenge tariffs, but House is unlikely to take any similar actionThe US Senate took a stand against Donald Trump’s global tariffs affecting more than 100 countries on Thursday, voting to nullify the so-called “reciprocal” tariffs.Four Republicans joined with all Democrats to vote 51-47 on a resolution to end the base-level tariffs that the president put into place via executive order. Continue reading...
items.content: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to challenge tariffs, but House is unlikely to take any similar actionThe US Senate took a stand against Donald Trump’s global tariffs affecting more than 100 countries on Thursday, voting to nullify the so-called “reciprocal” tariffs.Four Republicans joined with all Democrats to vote 51-47 on a resolution to end the base-level tariffs that the president put into place via executive order. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump directs Pentagon to match Russia and China in nuclear weapons testing
items.standfirst: US president makes threat after Russian nuclear-powered weapons tests and shortly before meeting with Chinese leaderDonald Trump has instructed the Pentagon to immediately start matching other nuclear powers in their testing of nuclear weapons, specifically citing Russia and China.In a post to Truth Social, Trump said “because of other countries’ testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately.” Continue reading...
items.content: US president makes threat after Russian nuclear-powered weapons tests and shortly before meeting with Chinese leaderDonald Trump has instructed the Pentagon to immediately start matching other nuclear powers in their testing of nuclear weapons, specifically citing Russia and China.In a post to Truth Social, Trump said “because of other countries’ testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Senate voted to reject Trump's global tariffs on over 100 countries.
Four Republicans joined Democrats to reject the tariffs.
Trump instructed the Pentagon to match nuclear weapons testing.
He cited Russia and China as examples.
Trump made the instruction shortly before meeting with the Chinese leader.
